headline.main: Liposuction Grows Safer As Less Fat Is Removed

docs.abstract: Article on advances and changing techniques that are making lipoplasty, formerly called liposuction, safer; notes surgeons no longer routinely combine lipoplasty with other major surgery and are using smaller surgical tools and removing smaller amounts of fat; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Cindy Laney, a former aerobics instructor, often runs five miles and lifts weights. ''But I always had these bulges around my middle that no amount of dieting or exercise would get rid of,'' she says. This year, Ms. Laney, 36, decided to have liposuction surgery. She had about four pounds of fat sucked from her midsection and says she is thrilled with the results.

headline.main: Can the Placebo Treat Depression? That Depends

docs.abstract: Dr Richard A Friedman Behavior column explores question of whether placebos are as effective as antidepressants in treating depression; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A patient of mine who had been depressed gleefully announced that he was going to stop his antidepressant because he had just read in the news that placebos were as effective as antidepressants. A provocative simple claim, but is it true? Suddenly, the placebo effect has made a comeback after having been supposedly debunked last year by a group of Danish researchers. In a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Asbjorn Hrobjartsson reported that placebos were no more effective than doing nothing in a variety of medical illnesses like hypertension, asthma and obesity. As a result, many researchers pronounced the placebo effect a myth. Perhaps this is true for the medical disorders in this study, but what about the placebo response in depression, which was unexamined in this meta-analysis?
docs.snippet: A patient of mine who had been depressed gleefully announced that he was going to stop his antidepressant because he had just read in the news that placebos were as effective as antidepressants. A provocative simple claim, but is it true?   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Should Hospitals Allow Fast Food?'' (Business Diary, June 16), which cited a study showing that more than a third of the nation's top hospitals have fast food on the premises:

headline.main: Bills Aplenty As Session Winds Down In Albany

docs.abstract: New York State Legislature approves 66 bills in frenzy of last-minute lawmaking; among bills passed is one under which guardians of mentally retarded people would be permitted to remove them from life-support machines if they have no chance of survival; another would ban sale of dog and cat meat or products containing their fur; another bill would solemnize hundreds of marriages performed by man who posed as rabbi in southern New York; another bill authorizes State Health Department to study health problems of overweight people, legislation known as Obesity Prevention Act; another bill would authorize study of infections transmitted by machines doctors use to examine colons (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The guardians of mentally retarded people would be permitted to remove them from life-support machines if they had no chance of survival, under a bill the Legislature passed in a frenzy of last-minute lawmaking on Thursday night. In the flood of unheralded legislation approved in the final hours of the official legislative session were measures both comic and extremely serious. In all, 66 bills passed both houses. One would ban the sale of dog and cat meat or products containing their fur. Another would solemnize the hundreds of marriages performed by a man who posed as a rabbi in southern New York. Both houses passed a bill authorizing the State Health Department to study health problems of overweight people, legislation known as the ''Obesity Prevention Act.'' Another bill orders up a study of infections transmitted by the machines doctors use to examine colons.
